A Nice Labelling for Tree-Like
Event Structures of Degree 333

Luigi Santocanale
Abstract

We address the problem of finding nice labellings for event structures of degree 333. We develop a minimum theory by which we prove that the labelling number of an event structure of degree 333 is bounded by a linear function of the height. The main theorem we present in this paper states that event structures of degree 333 whose causality order is a tree have a nice labelling with 333 colors. Finally, we exemplify how to use this theorem to construct upper bounds for the labelling number of other event structures of degree 333.

1 Introduction

Event structures, introduced in [1], are nowadays a widely recognized model of true concurrent computation and have found many uses since then. They are an intermediate abstract model that make it possible to relate other more concrete models such as Petri Nets or higher dimensional automata [2]. They provide formal semantics of process calculi [3, 4]. More recently, logicians became interested in event structures with the aim of constructing models of proof systems that are invariant under the equalities induced by the cut elimination procedure [5, 6].

Our interest for event structures stems from the fact that they combine distinct approaches to the modeling of concurrent computation. On one side, language theorists have developed the theory of partially commutative monoids [7] as the basic language to approach concurrency. On the other hand, the framework of domain theory and, ultimately, order theoretic ideas have often been proposed as the proper tools to handle concurrency, see for example [8]. In this paper we pursue a combinatorial problem that lies at the intersection of these two approaches. It is the problem of finding nice labellings for event structures of fixed degree. To our knowledge, this problem has not been investigated any longer since it was posed and partially solved in [9].

Let us recall that an event structure is made up of a set of local events Eùê∏E which is ordered by a causality relation ‚â§\leq. Moreover, a concurrency relation ‚å¢‚å¢\frown, that may only relate causally independent events, is given. A global state of the computation is modeled as a clique of the concurrency relation. Global states may be organized into a poset, the coherent domain of an event structure, which represents all the concurrent non-deterministic executions of a system. Roughly speaking, the nice labelling problem consists in representing the coherent domain of an event structure as a poset of traces or, more precisely, pomsets. That is, such a domain should be reconstructed using the standard ingredients of trace theory: an alphabet Œ£Œ£\Sigma, a local independence relation IùêºI, and a prefix closed subset of the free monoid LùêøL, see [10, 11]. By the general theory relating traces to ordered sets, the problem always has a solution (Œ£,I,L)Œ£ùêºùêø(\Sigma,I,L). We are asked to find a solution with the cardinality of the alphabet Œ£Œ£\Sigma minimal. The problem is actually equivalent to a graph coloring problem in that we can associate to an event structure a graph, of which we are asked to compute the chromatic number. The degree of an event structure is the maximal number of upper covers of some elements in the associated domain. Under the graph theoretic translation of the problem, the degree coincides with the clique number, and therefore it is a lower bound for the cardinality of a solution. A main contribution in [9] was to prove that event structures of degree 222 have a nice labelling with 222 letters, i.e. they have a solution (Œ£,I,L)Œ£ùêºùêø(\Sigma,I,L) with card‚Äã(Œ£)=2cardŒ£2\mathrm{card}(\Sigma)=2. On the other hand, it was proved there that event structures of higher degrees may require more letters than the degree.

The labelling problem may be thought to be a generalization of the problem of covering a poset by disjoint chains. Dilworth‚Äôs Theorem [12] states that the minimal cardinality of such a cover equals the maximal cardinality of an antichain. This theorem and the results of [9] constitute the few knowledge on the problem presently available to us. For example, we cannot state that there is some fixed k>nùëòùëõk>n for which every event structure of degree nùëõn has a nice labelling with at most kùëòk letters. In light of standard graph theoretic results [13], the above statement should not be taken for granted.

We present here our first results on the nice labelling problem for event structures of degree 333. We develop a minimum theory that shows that the graph of a degree 333 event structure, when restricted to an antichain, is almost acyclic and can be colored with 333 letters. This observation allows to construct an upper bound to the labelling number of such event structure as a linear function of its height. We prove then our main theorem stating that event structures of degree 333, whose causality order is a tree, have a nice labelling with 333 letters. Let us just say that such an event structure may represent a concurrent system where some processes are only allowed to fork or to take local nondeterministic choices. Finally, we exemplify how to use this theorem to construct upper bounds for the labelling number of other event structures of degree 333. In some simple cases, we obtain constant upper bounds to the labelling number, i.e. upper bounds that are functions of no parameter.

While these results do not answer the general problem, that of computing the labelling number of degree 333 event structures, we are aware that graph coloring problems may be difficult to answer. Thus we decided to present these results and share the knowledge so far acquired and also to encourage other researchers to pursue the problem. Let us mention why we believe that this and other problems in the combinatorics of concurrency deserve to be deeply investigated. The theory of event structures is now being applied within verification. A model checker, POEM, presently developed in Marseilles, makes explicit use of trace theory and of the theory of partial orders to represent the state space of a concurrent system [14]. The combinatorics of posets is there exploited to achieve an the efficient exploration of the global states of concurrent systems [15]. Thus, having a solid theoretical understanding of such combinatorics is, for us, a prerequisite and a complement for designing efficient algorithms for these kind of tools.

The paper is structured as follows. After recalling the order theoretic concepts we shall use, we introduce event structures and the nice labelling problem in section 2. In section 3 we develop the first properties of event structures of degree 333. As a result, we devise an upper bound for the labelling number of such event structures as a linear function of the height. In section 4 we present our main result stating that event structures whose underlying order is a tree may be labeled with 333 colors. In section 5 we develop a general approach to construct upper bounds to the labelling number of event structures of degree 333. Using this approach and the results of the previous section, we compute a constant upper bound for a class of degree 333 event structures that have some simplifying properties and which are consequently called simple.

Order Theoretic Preliminaries.

We shall introduce event structures in the next section. For the moment being let us anticipate that part of an event structure is a set Eùê∏E of events which is partially ordered by a causality relation ‚â§\leq. In this paper we shall heavily make use of order theoretic concepts. We introduce them here together with the notation that shall be used. All these concepts will apply to the poset ‚ü®E,‚â§‚ü©ùê∏\langle E,\leq\rangle of an event structure.

A finite poset is a pair ‚ü®P,‚â§‚ü©ùëÉ\langle P,\leq\rangle where PùëÉP is a finite set and ‚â§\leq is a reflexive, transitive and antisymmetric relation on PùëÉP. A subset X‚äÜPùëãùëÉX\subseteq P is a lower set if y‚â§x‚ààXùë¶ùë•ùëãy\leq x\in X implies y‚ààXùë¶ùëãy\in X. If Y‚äÜPùëåùëÉY\subseteq P, then we denote by ‚ÜìY‚Üìabsentùëå\downarrow\!Y the least lower set containing YùëåY. The explicit formula for ‚ÜìY‚Üìabsentùëå\downarrow\!Y is

‚ÜìY‚Üìabsentùëå\displaystyle\downarrow\!Y ={x‚ààP|‚àÉy‚ààY‚Äã¬†s.t.¬†‚Äãx‚â§y}.absentconditional-setùë•ùëÉùë¶ùëå¬†s.t.¬†ùë•ùë¶\displaystyle=\{\,x\in P\,|\,\exists y\in Y\textrm{ s.t. }x\leq y\,\}\,.

Two elements x,y‚ààPùë•ùë¶ùëÉx,y\in P are comparable if and only if either x‚â§yùë•ùë¶x\leq y or y‚â§xùë¶ùë•y\leq x. We write x‚âÉysimilar-to-or-equalsùë•ùë¶x\simeq y to mean that x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are comparable. A chain is sequence x0,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•0‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{0},\ldots,x_{n} of elements of PùëÉP such that x0<x1<‚Ä¶<xnsubscriptùë•0subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{0}<x_{1}<\ldots<x_{n}. The integer nùëõn is the length of the chain. The height of an element x‚ààPùë•ùëÉx\in P, noted 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(x)0ùëùùë°ùë•0pt(x), is the length of the longest chain in ‚Üì{x}‚Üìabsentùë•\downarrow\!\{\,x\,\}. The height of PùëÉP is max‚Å°{‚Äâ0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(x)|x‚ààP}conditional‚Äâ0ùëùùë°ùë•ùë•ùëÉ\max\{\,0pt(x)\,|\,x\in P\,\}. An antichain is a subset X‚äÜPùëãùëÉX\subseteq P such that x‚âÉÃ∏ynot-similar-to-or-equalsùë•ùë¶x\not\simeq y for each pair x,y‚ààXùë•ùë¶ùëãx,y\in X. The width of ‚ü®P,‚â§‚ü©ùëÉ\langle P,\leq\rangle, noted 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(P,‚â§)0ùëùùë°ùëÉ0pt(P,\leq), is the integer max‚Å°{card‚Äã(A)|A‚Äã¬†is an antichain}conditionalcardùê¥ùê¥¬†is an antichain\max\{\,\mathrm{card}(A)\,|\,A\text{ is an antichain}\,\}. If the interval {z‚ààP|x‚â§z‚â§y}conditional-setùëßùëÉùë•ùëßùë¶\{\,z\in P\,|\,x\leq z\leq y\,\} is the two elements set {x,y}ùë•ùë¶\{\,x,y\,\}, then we say that xùë•x is a lower cover of yùë¶y or that yùë¶y is an upper cover of xùë•x. We denote this relation by x‚â∫yprecedesùë•ùë¶x\prec y. The Hasse diagram of ‚ü®P,‚â§‚ü©ùëÉ\langle P,\leq\rangle is the directed graph ‚ü®P,‚â∫‚ü©ùëÉprecedes\langle P,\prec\rangle. For x‚ààPùë•ùëÉx\in P, the degree of xùë•x, noted deg‚Å°(x)degreeùë•\deg(x), is the number of upper covers of xùë•x. We shall denote by f‚Äã(x)fùë•\mathrm{f}(x) the number of lower covers of xùë•x (i.e. the indegree of xùë•x in the Hasse diagram). The poset ‚ü®P,‚â§‚ü©ùëÉ\langle P,\leq\rangle is graded if x‚â∫yprecedesùë•ùë¶x\prec y implies 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(y)=0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(y)+10ùëùùë°ùë¶0ùëùùë°ùë¶10pt(y)=0pt(y)+1.

2 Event Structures and the Nice Labelling Problem

Event structures are a basic model of concurrency introduced in [1]. The definition we present here is from [2].

Definition 1

An event structure is a triple ‚Ñ∞=‚ü®E,‚â§,ùíû‚ü©‚Ñ∞ùê∏ùíû\mathcal{E}=\langle E,\leq,\mathcal{C}\rangle such that

  • ‚Ä¢

    ‚ü®E,‚â§‚ü©ùê∏\langle E,\leq\rangle is a poset, such that for each x‚ààEùë•ùê∏x\in E the lower set ‚Üì{x}‚Üìabsentùë•\downarrow\!\{\,x\,\} is finite,

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} is a collection of subsets of Eùê∏E such that:

    1. 1.

      {x}‚ààùíûùë•ùíû\{\,x\,\}\in\mathcal{C} for each x‚ààEùë•ùê∏x\in E,

    2. 2.

      X‚äÜY‚ààùíûùëãùëåùíûX\subseteq Y\in\mathcal{C} implies X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C},

    3. 3.

      X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C} implies ‚ÜìX‚ààùíû‚Üìabsentùëãùíû\downarrow\!X\in\mathcal{C}.

The order ‚â§\leq of an event structure ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is known as the causality relation between events. The collection ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} is known as the set of configurations of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E}. A configuration X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C} of causally unrelated events ‚Äì that is, an antichain w.r.t. ‚â§\leq ‚Äì is a sort of snapshot of the global state of some distributed computation. A snapshot XùëãX may be transformed into a description of the computation that takes into account its history. This is done by adding to XùëãX the events that causally have determined events in XùëãX. That is, the history aware description is the lower set ‚ÜìX‚Üìabsentùëã\downarrow\!X generated by XùëãX.

Two elements x,y‚ààEùë•ùë¶ùê∏x,y\in E are said to be concurrent if x‚âÉÃ∏ynot-similar-to-or-equalsùë•ùë¶x\not\simeq y and there exists X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C} such that x,y‚ààXùë•ùë¶ùëãx,y\in X. Two concurrent elements will be thereby noted by x‚å¢y‚å¢ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y. It is useful to introduce a weakened version of the concurrency relation where we allow elements to be comparable: x‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãyùë•‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y if and only if x‚å¢y‚å¢ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y or x‚âÉysimilar-to-or-equalsùë•ùë¶x\simeq y. Equivalently, x‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãyùë•‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y if and only if there exists X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C} such that x,y‚ààXùë•ùë¶ùëãx,y\in X. In many concrete models the set of configurations is completely determined by the concurrency relation.

Definition 2

An event structure ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is coherent if ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} is the set of cliques of the weak concurrency relation: X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C} if and only if x‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãyùë•‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y for every pair of elements x,y‚ààXùë•ùë¶ùëãx,y\in X.

Coherent event structures are also known as event structures with binary conflict. To understand the naming let us explicitely introduce the conflict relation and two other derived relations:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Conflict: x‚å£y‚å£ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\smile$}y if and only if x‚âÉÃ∏ynot-similar-to-or-equalsùë•ùë¶x\not\simeq y and x‚Äã‚å¢ / ‚Äãyùë•‚å¢ / ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$/$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Minimal conflict: x‚Äã¬Ø ¬Ø ‚Äãyùë•¬Ø ¬Ø ùë¶x\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}\parbox{5.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}\,y if and only (i) x‚å£y‚å£ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\smile$}y, (ii) x‚Ä≤<xsuperscriptùë•‚Ä≤ùë•x^{\prime}<x implies x‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãysuperscriptùë•‚Ä≤‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë¶x^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y, and (iii) y‚Ä≤<ysuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë¶y^{\prime}<y implies x‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãy‚Ä≤ùë•‚å¢ ‚âÉ superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y^{\prime}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Orthogonality: x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y if and only if x‚Äã¬Ø ¬Ø ‚Äãyùë•¬Ø ¬Ø ùë¶x\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}\parbox{5.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}\,y or x‚å¢y‚å¢ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y.

A coherent event structure is completely described by a triple ‚ü®E,‚â§,‚å¢‚ü©ùê∏‚å¢\langle E,\leq,\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\rangle where the latter is a symmetric relation subject to the following condition: x‚å¢y‚å¢ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y and z‚â§xùëßùë•z\leq x implies z‚å¢y‚å¢ùëßùë¶z\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y or z‚â§yùëßùë¶z\leq y. Similarly, a coherent event structure is completely determined by the order and the conflict relation. In this paper we shall deal with coherent event structures only and, from now on, event structure will be a synonym for coherent event structure.

We shall focus mainly on the orthogonality relation. Let us observe that two orthogonal elements are called independent in [9]. We prefer however not to use this naming: we shall frequently make use of standard graph theoretic language and argue about cliques, not on their dual, independent sets. The orthogonality relation clearly is symmetric and moreover it inherits from the concurrency relation the following property: if x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y and z‚â§xùëßùë•z\leq x, then z‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùëß¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y or z‚â§yùëßùë¶z\leq y.

Definition 3

A nice labelling of an event structure ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is a pair (Œª,Œ£)ùúÜŒ£(\lambda,\Sigma), where Œ£Œ£\Sigma is a finite alphabet and Œª:E‚ü∂Œ£:ùúÜ‚ü∂ùê∏Œ£\lambda:E\longrightarrow\Sigma is such that Œª‚Äã(x)‚â†Œª‚Äã(y)ùúÜùë•ùúÜùë¶\lambda(x)\neq\lambda(y) whenever x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y.

That is, if we let ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) ‚Äì the graph of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} ‚Äì be the pair ‚ü®E,‚å¢¬Ø‚ü©ùê∏¬Ø‚å¢\langle E,{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}\rangle, a labelling of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is a coloring of the graph ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}). For a graph Gùê∫G, let Œ≥‚Äã(G)ùõæùê∫\gamma(G) denote its chromatic number. Let us say then that the labelling number of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞))ùõæùí¢‚Ñ∞\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E})). The nice labelling problem for a class ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} of event structures amounts to computing the number

Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¶)ùõæùí¶\displaystyle\gamma(\mathcal{K}) =max‚Å°{Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞))|‚Ñ∞‚ààùí¶}.absentconditionalùõæùí¢‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞ùí¶\displaystyle=\max\{\,\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}))\,|\,\mathcal{E}\in\mathcal{K}\,\}\,.

To understand the origins of this problem, let us recall the definition of the domain of an event structure.

Definition 4

The domain ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) of an event structure ‚Ñ∞=‚ü®E,‚â§,ùíû‚ü©‚Ñ∞ùê∏ùíû\mathcal{E}=\langle E,\leq,\mathcal{C}\rangle is the collection of lower sets in ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, ordered by subset inclusion.

Following a standard axiomatization in theoretical computer science [2] ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is a stable domain which is coherent if ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is coherent. Stable means that ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is essentially a distributive lattice. As a matter of fact, if ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is finite, then a possible alternative axiomatization of the poset ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is as follows. It is easily seen that the collection ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is closed under binary intersections, hence it is a finite meet semilattice without a top element, a chopped lattice in the sense of [16, Chapter 4]. Also the chopped lattice is distributive, meaning that whenever X,Y,Z‚ààùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùëãùëåùëçùíü‚Ñ∞X,Y,Z\in\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) and X‚à™Y‚ààùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùëãùëåùíü‚Ñ∞X\cup Y\in\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}), then Z‚à©(X‚à™Y)=(Z‚à©X)‚à™(Z‚à©Y)ùëçùëãùëåùëçùëãùëçùëåZ\cap(X\cup Y)=(Z\cap X)\cup(Z\cap Y). It can be shown that every distributive chopped lattice is isomorphic to the domain of a finite ‚Äì not necessarily coherent ‚Äì event structure.

Lemma 1

A set {x1,‚Ä¶,xn}subscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõ\{\,x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\,\} is a clique in the graph ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) iff there exists I‚ààùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùêºùíü‚Ñ∞I\in\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) such that I‚à™{xi}ùêºsubscriptùë•ùëñI\cup\{\,x_{i}\,\}, i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, are distinct upper covers of IùêºI in the domain ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}).

The Lemma shows that a nice labelling Œª:E‚ü∂Œ£:ùúÜ‚ü∂ùê∏Œ£\lambda:E\longrightarrow\Sigma allows to label the edges of the Hasse diagram of ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) so that: (i) outgoing edges from the same source vertex have distinct labels, (ii) perspective edges ‚Äì i.e. edges I0‚â∫I1precedessubscriptùêº0subscriptùêº1I_{0}\prec I_{1} and J0‚â∫J1precedessubscriptùêΩ0subscriptùêΩ1J_{0}\prec J_{1} such that I0=I1‚à©J0subscriptùêº0subscriptùêº1subscriptùêΩ0I_{0}=I_{1}\cap J_{0} and J1=I1‚à™J0subscriptùêΩ1subscriptùêº1subscriptùêΩ0J_{1}=I_{1}\cup J_{0} ‚Äì have the same label. These conditions are necessary and sufficient to show that ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}) is order isomorphic to a consistent (but not complete) set of PùëÉP-traces (or pomsets) on the alphabet Œ£Œ£\Sigma in the sense of [10].

The degree of an event structure ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is the degree of the domain ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}), that is, the maximum number of upper covers of a lower set IùêºI within the poset ùíü‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùíü‚Ñ∞\mathcal{D}(\mathcal{E}). Lemma 1 shows that the degree of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is equal to the size of a maximal clique in ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}), i.e. to the clique number of ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}). Henceforth, the degree of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is a lower bound to Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞))ùõæùí¢‚Ñ∞\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E})). The following Theorems state the few results on the nice labelling problem that are available in the literature.

Theorem 2.1 (see [12])

Let ùí©‚Äãùíûnùí©subscriptùíûùëõ\mathcal{NC}_{n} be the class of event structures of degree at most nùëõn with empty conflict relation. Then Œ≥‚Äã(ùí©‚Äãùíûn)=nùõæùí©subscriptùíûùëõùëõ\gamma(\mathcal{NC}_{n})=n.

Theorem 2.2 (see [9])

Let ùí¶nsubscriptùí¶ùëõ\mathcal{K}_{n} be the class of event structures of degree at most nùëõn. Then Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¶n)=nùõæsubscriptùí¶ùëõùëõ\gamma(\mathcal{K}_{n})=n if n‚â§2ùëõ2n\leq 2 and Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¶n)‚â•n+1ùõæsubscriptùí¶ùëõùëõ1\gamma(\mathcal{K}_{n})\geq n+1 otherwise.

The last theorem has been our starting point for investigating the nice labelling problem for event structures of degree 333.

3 Cycles and Antichains

From now own, in this and the following sections, ‚Ñ∞=‚ü®E,‚â§,ùíû‚ü©‚Ñ∞ùê∏ùíû\mathcal{E}=\langle E,\leq,\mathcal{C}\rangle will denote a coherent event structure of degree at most 333. We begin our investigation of the nice labelling problem by studying the restriction to an antichain of the graph ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}). The main tool we shall use is the following Lemma. It is a straightforward generalization of [9, Lemma 2.2] to degree 333. In [17] we proposed generalizations of this Lemma to higher degrees, pointing out their strong geometrical flavor.

Proposition 1

Corollary 1

Any subgraph of ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) induced by an antichain can be colored with 333 colors.

Proof

Since the only cycles have length at most 333, such an induced graph is chordal and its clique number is 333. It is well known that the chromatic number of chordal graphs equals their clique number [18]. ‚àé

In the rest of this section we exploit the previous observations to construct upper bounds for the labelling number of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E}. We remark that these upper bounds might appear either too abstract, or too trivial. On the other hand, we believe that they well illustrate the kind of problems that arise when trying to build complex event structures that might have labelling number greater than 444.

A stratifying function for ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is a function h:E‚ü∂‚Ñï:‚Ñé‚ü∂ùê∏‚Ñïh:E\longrightarrow\mathbb{N} such that, for each n‚â•0ùëõ0n\geq 0, the set {x‚ààE|h‚Äã(x)=n}conditional-setùë•ùê∏‚Ñéùë•ùëõ\{\,x\in E\,|\,h(x)=n\,\} is an antichain. The height function is a stratifying function. Also œÇ‚Äã(x)=card‚Äã{y‚ààE|y<x}ùúçùë•cardconditional-setùë¶ùê∏ùë¶ùë•\varsigma(x)=\mathrm{card}\{\,y\in E\,|\,y<x\,\} is a stratifying function. With respect to a stratifying function h‚Ñéh the h‚Ñéh-skewness of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is defined by

skewh‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)subscriptskew‚Ñé‚Ñ∞\displaystyle\mathrm{skew}_{h}(\mathcal{E}) =max‚Å°{|h‚Äã(x)‚àíh‚Äã(y)||x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãy}.absentconditional‚Ñéùë•‚Ñéùë¶ùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶\displaystyle=\max\{\,|h(x)-h(y)|\,|\,x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y\,\}\,.
More generally, the skewness of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is defined by
skew‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)skew‚Ñ∞\displaystyle\mathrm{skew}(\mathcal{E}) =min‚Å°{skewh‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)|h‚Äã¬†is a stratifying function¬†}.absentconditionalsubscriptskew‚Ñé‚Ñ∞‚Ñé¬†is a stratifying function¬†\displaystyle=\min\{\,\mathrm{skew}_{h}(\mathcal{E})\,|\,h\text{ is a stratifying function }\,\}\,.
Proposition 2

If skew‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)<nskew‚Ñ∞ùëõ\mathrm{skew}(\mathcal{E})<n then Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞))‚â§3‚Äãnùõæùí¢‚Ñ∞3ùëõ\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}))\leq 3n.

Proof

Let h‚Ñéh be a stratifying function such that |h‚Äã(x)‚àíh‚Äã(y)|<n‚Ñéùë•‚Ñéùë¶ùëõ|h(x)-h(y)|<n whenever x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y. For each k‚â•0ùëò0k\geq 0, let Œªk:{x‚ààE|h‚Äã(x)=k}‚ü∂{a,b,c}:subscriptùúÜùëò‚ü∂conditional-setùë•ùê∏‚Ñéùë•ùëòùëéùëèùëê\lambda_{k}:\{\,x\in E\,|\,h(x)=k\,\}\longrightarrow\{\,a,b,c\,\} be a coloring of the graph induced by {x‚ààE|h‚Äã(x)=k}conditional-setùë•ùê∏‚Ñéùë•ùëò\{\,x\in E\,|\,h(x)=k\,\}. Define Œª:E‚ü∂{a,b,c}√ó{‚Äâ0,‚Ä¶,n‚àí1}:ùúÜ‚ü∂ùê∏ùëéùëèùëê‚Äâ0‚Ä¶ùëõ1\lambda:E\longrightarrow\{\,a,b,c\,\}\times\{\,0,\ldots,n-1\,\} as follows:

Œª‚Äã(x)ùúÜùë•\displaystyle\lambda(x) =(Œªh‚Äã(x)‚Äã(x),h‚Äã(x)‚Äãmod‚Äãn).absentsubscriptùúÜ‚Ñéùë•ùë•‚Ñéùë•modùëõ\displaystyle=(\lambda_{h(x)}(x),h(x)\,\mathrm{mod}\,n)\,.

Let us suppose that x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y and h‚Äã(x)‚â•h‚Äã(y)‚Ñéùë•‚Ñéùë¶h(x)\geq h(y), so that 0‚â§h‚Äã(x)‚àíh‚Äã(y)<n0‚Ñéùë•‚Ñéùë¶ùëõ0\leq h(x)-h(y)<n. In both cases we obtain Œª‚Äã(x)‚â†Œª‚Äã(y)ùúÜùë•ùúÜùë¶\lambda(x)\neq\lambda(y). ‚àé

An immediate consequence of Proposition 2 is the following upper bound for the labelling number of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E}:

Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞))ùõæùí¢‚Ñ∞\displaystyle\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E})) ‚â§3‚Äã(0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)+1).absent30ùëùùë°‚Ñ∞1\displaystyle\leq 3(0pt(\mathcal{E})+1)\,.

To appreciate the upper bound, consider that another approximation to the labelling number of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is provided by Dilworth‚Äôs Theorem [12], stating that Œ≥‚Äã(ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞))‚â§0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùõæùí¢‚Ñ∞0ùëùùë°‚Ñ∞\gamma(\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}))\leq 0pt(\mathcal{E}). To compare the two bounds, consider that there exist event structures of degree 333 whose width is an exponential function of the height.

4 An Optimal Nice Labelling for Trees and Forests

We prove in this section the main contribution of this paper. Assuming that ‚ü®E,‚â§‚ü©ùê∏\langle E,\leq\rangle is a tree or a forest, then we define a labelling with 333 colors, and prove it is a nice labelling. Since clearly we can construct a tree which needs at least three colors, such a labelling is optimal. Before defining the labelling, we shall develop a small amount of observations.

Definition 5

We say that two distinct events are twins if they have the same set of lower covers.

Clearly if x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are twins, then z<xùëßùë•z<x if and only if z<yùëßùë¶z<y. More importantly, if x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are twins, then the relation x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y holds. As a matter of fact, if x‚Ä≤<xsuperscriptùë•‚Ä≤ùë•x^{\prime}<x then x‚Ä≤<ysuperscriptùë•‚Ä≤ùë¶x^{\prime}<y, hence x‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãysuperscriptùë•‚Ä≤‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë¶x^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y. Similarly, if y‚Ä≤<ysuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë¶y^{\prime}<y then y‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãxsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë•y^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}x. It follows that a set of events having the same lower covers form a clique in ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}), hence it has at most the degree of an event structure, 333 in the present case. To introduce the next Lemmas, if x‚ààY‚äÜEùë•ùëåùê∏x\in Y\subseteq E, define

OxYsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùëåùë•\displaystyle O^{Y}_{x} ={z|z‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãx‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äãy‚â∞z,¬†forall¬†‚Äãy‚ààY}.absentconditional-setùëßformulae-sequencenot-less-than-or-equalsùëß¬Ø‚å¢ùë•¬†and¬†ùë¶ùëß¬†forall¬†ùë¶ùëå\displaystyle=\{\,z\,|\,z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x\textrm{ and }y\not\leq z,\text{ forall }y\in Y\,\}\,.

If Y={x,y}ùëåùë•ùë¶Y=\{\,x,y\,\}, then we shall abuse of notation and write Oxx,ysubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•O^{x,y}_{x}, Oxy,xsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë¶ùë•ùë•O^{y,x}_{x} as synonyms of OxYsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùëåùë•O^{Y}_{x}. Thus z‚ààOxx,yùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•z\in O^{x,y}_{x} if and only if z‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxùëß¬Ø‚å¢ùë•z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x and y‚â∞znot-less-than-or-equalsùë¶ùëßy\not\leq z.

Lemma 3

If x,y,zùë•ùë¶ùëßx,y,z are parwise distinct twins, then Ox{x,y,z}=‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùëßùë•O^{\{x,y,z\}}_{x}=\emptyset.

Proof

Let us suppose that w‚ààOx{x,y,z}ùë§subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùëßùë•w\in O^{\{x,y,z\}}_{x}. If w‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë§¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶w{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y, then w‚âÉzsimilar-to-or-equalsùë§ùëßw\simeq z by Lemma 2. Hence w‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äã¬†/¬†‚Äãyùë§¬Ø‚å¢¬†/¬†ùë¶w{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}\parbox{8.33327pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$/$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}y and we can find w‚Ä≤‚â§wsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùë§w^{\prime}\leq w, y‚Ä≤‚â§ysuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë¶y^{\prime}\leq y such that w‚Ä≤‚Äã¬Ø ¬Ø ‚Äãy‚Ä≤superscriptùë§‚Ä≤¬Ø ¬Ø superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤w^{\prime}\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}\parbox{5.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}\,y^{\prime}. From w‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxùë§¬Ø‚å¢ùë•w{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x and w‚Ä≤<wsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùë§w^{\prime}<w, we deduce that w‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤¬Ø‚å¢ùë•w^{\prime}{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x or w‚Ä≤‚â§xsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùë•w^{\prime}\leq x. Therefore w‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤¬Ø‚å¢ùë•w^{\prime}{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x and {w‚Ä≤,x,y},{x,y,z}superscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùë•ùë¶ùë•ùë¶ùëß\{\,w^{\prime},x,y\,\},\{\,x,y,z\,\} are two 333-cliques sharing the same face {x,y}ùë•ùë¶\{\,x,y\,\}. As before, w‚Ä≤‚âÉzsimilar-to-or-equalssuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùëßw^{\prime}\simeq z, leading to a contradiction. ‚àé

Lemma 4

If x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are twins, then Oxx,y,Oyx,ysubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶O^{x,y}_{x},O^{x,y}_{y} are comparable w.r.t. set inclusion and Oxx,y‚à©Oyx,ysubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶O^{x,y}_{x}\cap O^{x,y}_{y} is a linear order.

Proof

We observe first that if z‚ààOxx,yùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•z\in O^{x,y}_{x} and w‚ààOyx,yùë§subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶w\in O^{x,y}_{y} then z‚âÉwsimilar-to-or-equalsùëßùë§z\simeq w. As a consequence Oxx,y‚à©Oyx,ysubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶O^{x,y}_{x}\cap O^{x,y}_{y} is linearly ordered.

Let us suppose that there exists z‚ààOxx,yùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•z\in O^{x,y}_{x} and w‚ààOyx,yùë§subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶w\in O^{x,y}_{y} such that z‚âÉÃ∏wnot-similar-to-or-equalsùëßùë§z\not\simeq w. Observe then that {z,x,y,w}ùëßùë•ùë¶ùë§\{\,z,x,y,w\,\} is an antichain: y‚â∞znot-less-than-or-equalsùë¶ùëßy\not\leq z, and z<yùëßùë¶z<y implies z<xùëßùë•z<x, which is not the case due to z‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxùëß¬Ø‚å¢ùë•z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x. Thus z‚âÉÃ∏ynot-similar-to-or-equalsùëßùë¶z\not\simeq y and similarly w‚âÉÃ∏xnot-similar-to-or-equalsùë§ùë•w\not\simeq x.

Since there cannot be a length 444 straight cycle, we deduce z‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äã¬†/¬†‚Äãwùëß¬Ø‚å¢¬†/¬†ùë§z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}\parbox{8.33327pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$/$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}w. Let z‚Ä≤‚â§zsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëßz^{\prime}\leq z and w‚Ä≤‚â§wsuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤ùë§w^{\prime}\leq w be such that z‚Ä≤‚Äã¬Ø ¬Ø ‚Äãw‚Ä≤superscriptùëß‚Ä≤¬Ø ¬Ø superscriptùë§‚Ä≤z^{\prime}\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}\parbox{5.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\raisebox{1.0pt}{$\overline{\hskip 10.0pt}$}$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}\,w^{\prime}. We claim first that z‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤¬Ø‚å¢ùë•z^{\prime}{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x. Otherwise, z‚Ä≤‚â§xsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùë•z^{\prime}\leq x and z‚Ä≤<xsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùë•z^{\prime}<x, since z‚Ä≤=xsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùë•z^{\prime}=x implies x‚â§zùë•ùëßx\leq z. Also it cannot be the case that y‚â§z‚Ä≤ùë¶superscriptùëß‚Ä≤y\leq z^{\prime}, since otherwise y‚â§zùë¶ùëßy\leq z. Similarly w‚Ä≤‚ààOyx,ysuperscriptùë§‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶w^{\prime}\in O^{x,y}_{y}. As before {z‚Ä≤,x,y,w‚Ä≤}superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùë•ùë¶superscriptùë§‚Ä≤\{\,z^{\prime},x,y,w^{\prime}\,\} is an antichain, hence z‚Ä≤,x,y,w‚Ä≤superscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùë•ùë¶superscriptùë§‚Ä≤z^{\prime},x,y,w^{\prime} also form a length 444 straight cycle, a contradiction.

Observe now that w‚â§z‚ààOxx,yùë§ùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•w\leq z\in O^{x,y}_{x} and w‚â∞xnot-less-than-or-equalsùë§ùë•w\not\leq x implies w‚ààOxx,yùë§subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•w\in O^{x,y}_{x}. Let z‚ààOxx,y‚àñOyx,yùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶z\in O^{x,y}_{x}\setminus O^{x,y}_{y}, pick any w‚ààOyx,yùë§subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶w\in O^{x,y}_{y} and recall that z,wùëßùë§z,w are comparable. We cannot have z‚â§wùëßùë§z\leq w since z‚â∞ynot-less-than-or-equalsùëßùë¶z\not\leq y implies then z‚ààOyx,yùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶z\in O^{x,y}_{y}. Hence w<z‚ààOxx,yùë§ùëßsubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•w<z\in O^{x,y}_{x} and w‚â∞xnot-less-than-or-equalsùë§ùë•w\not\leq x imply w‚ààOxx,yùë§subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•w\in O^{x,y}_{x} by the previous observation.‚àé

The following Lemma will prove to be the key observation in defining later a nice labelling.

Lemma 5

Let (x,y)ùë•ùë¶(x,y) (z,w)ùëßùë§(z,w) be two pairs of pairwise distinct twins such that z‚ààOxx,y‚à©Oyx,yùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùë•ùë•ùë¶superscriptsubscriptùëÇùë¶ùë•ùë¶z\in O_{x}^{x,y}\cap O_{y}^{x,y} and w‚â∞xnot-less-than-or-equalsùë§ùë•w\not\leq x. Then Ozw,z‚äÉOww,zsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùë§ùë§ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùëßùë§ùëßO_{z}^{w,z}\supset O_{w}^{w,z}.

Proof

If Ozw,z‚äÖOww,znot-superset-ofsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùëßùë§ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùë§ùë§ùëßO_{z}^{w,z}\not\supset O_{w}^{w,z}, then Ozw,z‚äÜOww,zsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùëßùë§ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëÇùë§ùë§ùëßO_{z}^{w,z}\subseteq O_{w}^{w,z} by Lemma 4. Since w‚â∞xnot-less-than-or-equalsùë§ùë•w\not\leq x and w‚â†yùë§ùë¶w\neq y, then w‚â∞ynot-less-than-or-equalsùë§ùë¶w\not\leq y. We have shown that x,y‚ààOzw,zùë•ùë¶superscriptsubscriptùëÇùëßùë§ùëßx,y\in O_{z}^{w,z}, hence x,y‚ààOww,zùë•ùë¶superscriptsubscriptùëÇùë§ùë§ùëßx,y\in O_{w}^{w,z}. It follows that {x,y,z,w}ùë•ùë¶ùëßùë§\{\,x,y,z,w\,\} is a size 444 clique, a contradiction.‚àé

We come now to discuss some subsets of Eùê∏E for which we shall prove that there exists a nice labelling with 333 letters. The intuitive reason for that is the presence of many twins.

Definition 6

A subset T‚äÜEùëáùê∏T\subseteq E is a tree if and only if

  • ‚Ä¢

    each x‚ààTùë•ùëáx\in T has exactly one lower cover œÄ‚Äã(x)‚ààEùúãùë•ùê∏\pi(x)\in E,

  • ‚Ä¢

    TùëáT is convex: x,z‚ààTùë•ùëßùëáx,z\in T and x<y<zùë•ùë¶ùëßx<y<z implies y‚ààTùë¶ùëáy\in T,

  • ‚Ä¢

    if x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are minimal in TùëáT, then œÄ‚Äã(x)=œÄ‚Äã(y)ùúãùë•ùúãùë¶\pi(x)=\pi(y).

If TùëáT is a tree and x‚ààTùë•ùëáx\in T, the height of xùë•x in TùëáT, noted 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã[T]‚Äã(x)0ùëùùë°delimited-[]ùëáùë•0pt[T](x), is the cardinality of the set {y‚ààT|y<x}conditional-setùë¶ùëáùë¶ùë•\{\,y\in T\,|\,y<x\,\}. A linear ordering ‚ä≤subgroup-of\lhd on TùëáT is said to be compatible with the height if it satisfies

0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã[T]‚Äã(x)<0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã[T]‚Äã(y)0ùëùùë°delimited-[]ùëáùë•0ùëùùë°delimited-[]ùëáùë¶\displaystyle 0pt[T](x)<0pt[T](y) implies¬†‚Äãx‚ä≤y.subgroup-ofimplies¬†ùë•ùë¶\displaystyle\textrm{ implies }x\lhd y\,. (HEIGHT)

It is not difficult to see that such a linear ordering always exists. With respect to such linear ordering, define

O‚ä≤‚Äã(x)subscriptùëÇsubgroup-ofùë•\displaystyle O_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x) ={y‚ààT|y‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãx‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äãy‚ä≤x},x‚ààT.formulae-sequenceabsentconditional-setùë¶ùëásubgroup-ofùë¶¬Ø‚å¢ùë•¬†and¬†ùë¶ùë•ùë•ùëá\displaystyle=\{\,y\in T\,|\,y{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x\textrm{ and }y\lhd x\,\}\,,\;\;\;\;x\in T.

Lemma 6

If y‚ààC‚ä≤‚Äã(x)ùë¶subscriptùê∂subgroup-ofùë•y\in C_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x) then x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are twins. Consequently there can be at most two elements in C‚ä≤‚Äã(x)subscriptùê∂subgroup-ofùë•C_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x).

Proof

If y‚ààC‚ä≤‚Äã(x)ùë¶subscriptùê∂subgroup-ofùë•y\in C_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x), then y‚ä≤xsubgroup-ofùë¶ùë•y\lhd x and 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã[T]‚Äã(y)‚â§0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã[T]‚Äã(x)0ùëùùë°delimited-[]ùëáùë¶0ùëùùë°delimited-[]ùëáùë•0pt[T](y)\leq 0pt[T](x). Since x,yùë•ùë¶x,y have exactly one lower cover, it follows that x,yùë•ùë¶x,y are twins. ‚àé

The previous observations motivate us to introduce the next Definition.

Definition 7

Let us say that x,y‚ààTùë•ùë¶ùëáx,y\in T are a proper pair of twins if they are distinct and {z|œÄ‚Äã(z)=œÄ‚Äã(x)}={x,y}conditional-setùëßùúãùëßùúãùë•ùë•ùë¶\{\,z\,|\,\pi(z)=\pi(x)\,\,\}=\{\,x,y\,\}. Oxx,y‚äÉOyx,ysubscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë¶subscriptsuperscriptùëÇùë•ùë¶ùë•\displaystyle O^{x,y}_{x}\supset O^{x,y}_{y} implies¬†‚Äãx‚ä≤y,subgroup-ofimplies¬†ùë•ùë¶\displaystyle\textrm{ implies }x\lhd y\,, (TWINS)

for each proper pair of twins x,yùë•ùë¶x,y.

Again is not difficult to see that such a linear order always exists and in the following we shall assume that ‚ä≤subgroup-of\lhd satisfies both (HEIGHT) and (TWINS).


We are ready to define a partial labelling of the event structure ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} whose domain is TùëáT. The labelling Œª:T‚ü∂Œ£:ùúÜ‚ü∂ùëáŒ£\lambda:T\longrightarrow\Sigma is defined by induction on ‚ä≤subgroup-of\lhd as follows:

    If x‚ààTùë•ùëáx\in T is principal and 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã[T]‚Äã(x)=00ùëùùë°delimited-[]ùëáùë•00pt[T](x)=0, then we let Œª‚Äã(x)=a0ùúÜùë•subscriptùëé0\lambda(x)=a_{0}.

  2. 2.

  3. 3.

    If xùë•x is not principal and L‚ä≤‚Äã(x)=‚àÖsubscriptùêøsubgroup-ofùë•L_{{\!}_{\!\lhd}}\!(x)=\emptyset, then, by Lemma 6, we let Œª‚Äã(x)ùúÜùë•\lambda(x) be the least symbol not in Œª‚Äã(C‚ä≤‚Äã(x))ùúÜsubscriptùê∂subgroup-ofùë•\lambda(C_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x)).

  4. 4.

    • ‚Ä¢

      by Lemma 8 C‚ä≤‚Äã(x)={y}subscriptùê∂subgroup-ofùë•ùë¶C_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x)=\{\,y\,\} is a singleton and x,yùë•ùë¶x,y is a proper pair of twins,

    We let Œª‚Äã(x)ùúÜùë•\lambda(x) be the unique symbol not in Œª‚Äã({y,z0})ùúÜùë¶subscriptùëß0\lambda(\{\,y,z_{0}\,\}).

Proposition 3

For each x,y‚ààTùë•ùë¶ùëáx,y\in T, if x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y then Œª‚Äã(x)‚â†Œª‚Äã(y)ùúÜùë•ùúÜùë¶\lambda(x)\neq\lambda(y).

Proof

It suffices to prove that Œª‚Äã(y)‚â†Œª‚Äã(x)ùúÜùë¶ùúÜùë•\lambda(y)\neq\lambda(x) if y‚ààO‚ä≤‚Äã(x)ùë¶subscriptùëÇsubgroup-ofùë•y\in O_{{\!}_{\!\!\lhd}}\!(x). The statement is proved by induction on ‚ä≤subgroup-of\lhd. Let us suppose the statement is true for all z‚ä≤xsubgroup-ofùëßùë•z\lhd x.

The obvious corollary of Proposition 3 is that if ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is already a sort of tree, then it has a nice labelling with 333 letters. We state this fact as the following Theorem, after we having made precise the meaning of the phrase ‚Äú‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is a sort of tree.‚Äù

Definition 8

Let us say that ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} is a forest if every element has at most one lower cover. Let ‚Ñ±3subscript‚Ñ±3\mathcal{F}_{3} be the class of event structures of degree 333 that are forests.

Theorem 4.1

The labelling number of the class ‚Ñ±3subscript‚Ñ±3\mathcal{F}_{3} is 333.

As a matter of fact, let ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} be a forest, and consider the event structure ‚Ñ∞‚ä•subscript‚Ñ∞bottom\mathcal{E}_{\bot} obtained from ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} by adding a new bottom element ‚ä•bottom\bot. Remark that the graph ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞‚ä•)ùí¢subscript‚Ñ∞bottom\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}_{\bot}) is the same graph as ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) apart from the fact that an isolated vertex ‚ä•bottom\bot has been added. The set of events Eùê∏E is a tree within ‚Ñ∞‚ä•subscript‚Ñ∞bottom\mathcal{E}_{\bot}, hence the graph induced by Eùê∏E in ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞‚ä•)ùí¢subscript‚Ñ∞bottom\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}_{\bot}) can be colored with three colors. But this graph is exactly ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}).

5 More Upper Bounds

The results presented in the previous section exemplify a remarkable property of event structures of degree 333: many types of subsets of events induce a subgraph of ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) that can be colored with 333 colors. These include antichains by Corollary 1, trees by Proposition 3, and lower sets in ùíûùíû\mathcal{C}, that is configurations of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E}. As a matter fact, if X‚ààùíûùëãùíûX\in\mathcal{C}, then 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(X)‚â§30ùëùùë°ùëã30pt(X)\leq 3, so that such a subset can be labeled with 333 letters by Dilworth‚Äôs Theorem. Also, recall that the star of an event x‚ààEùë•ùê∏x\in E is the subgraph of ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) induced by the subset {x}‚à™{y‚ààE|y‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãx}ùë•conditional-setùë¶ùê∏ùë¶¬Ø‚å¢ùë•\{\,x\,\}\cup\{\,y\in E\,|\,y{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x\,\}. A star can also be labeled with 333 letters. To understand the reason, let ùí©xsubscriptùí©ùë•\mathcal{N}_{x} be the event structure ‚ü®{y|y‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãx},‚â§x,‚å¢x‚ü©conditional-setùë¶ùë¶¬Ø‚å¢ùë•subscriptùë•subscript‚å¢ùë•\langle\{\,y\,|\,y{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x\,\},\leq_{x},\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}_{x}\rangle, where ‚â§xsubscriptùë•\leq_{x} and ‚å¢xsubscript‚å¢ùë•\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}_{x} are the restrictions of the causality and concurrency relations to the set of events of ùí©xsubscriptùí©ùë•{\cal N}_{x}.

Lemma 9

The degree of ùí©xsubscriptùí©ùë•\mathcal{N}_{x} is strictly less than deg‚Å°(‚Ñ∞)degree‚Ñ∞\deg(\mathcal{E}).

Proof

As a matter of fact, let us suppose that y‚Äã‚å¢¬Øx‚Äãzùë¶subscript¬Ø‚å¢ùë•ùëßy{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}_{x}z in ùí©xsubscriptùí©ùë•\mathcal{N}_{x} and y‚Ä≤<ysuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë¶y^{\prime}<y. If y‚Ä≤‚ààùí©xsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤subscriptùí©ùë•y^{\prime}\in\mathcal{N}_{x}, then y‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãzsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùëßy^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}z. If y‚Ä≤‚àâùí©xsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤subscriptùí©ùë•y^{\prime}\not\in\mathcal{N}_{x}, then y‚Ä≤<xsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë•y^{\prime}<x. It follows then from z‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãxùëß¬Ø‚å¢ùë•z{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}x and y‚Ä≤<xsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤ùë•y^{\prime}<x that y‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢ ‚âÉ ‚Äãxsuperscriptùë¶‚Ä≤‚å¢ ‚âÉ ùë•y^{\prime}\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}\parbox{10.00002pt}{\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}$\raisebox{-7.0pt}{$\simeq$}$\mbox{}\hfill\mbox{}}x. Hence, if deg‚Å°(‚Ñ∞)=3degree‚Ñ∞3\deg(\mathcal{E})=3, then deg‚Å°(ùí©x)‚â§2degreesubscriptùí©ùë•2\deg(\mathcal{N}_{x})\leq 2, and it can be labeled with 222 letters, by [9]. It follows that star of xùë•x can be labeled with 333 letters.

It might be asked whether this property can be exploited to construct nice labellings. The positive answer comes from a standard technique in graph theory [19]. Consider a partition ùí´={[z]‚à£z‚ààE}ùí´conditional-setdelimited-[]ùëßùëßùê∏{\cal P}=\{\,[z]\mid z\in E\,\} of the set of events such that each equivalence class [z]delimited-[]ùëß[z] has a labelling with 333 letters. Define the quotient graph ùí¢‚Äã(ùí´,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí´‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}({\cal P},\mathcal{E}) as follows: its vertexes are the equivalence classes of ùí´ùí´{\cal P} and [x]‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äã[y]delimited-[]ùë•¬Ø‚å¢delimited-[]ùë¶[x]{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}[y] if and only if there exists x‚Ä≤‚àà[x]superscriptùë•‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùë•x^{\prime}\in[x], y‚Ä≤‚àà[y]superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤delimited-[]ùë¶y^{\prime}\in[y] such that x‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãy‚Ä≤superscriptùë•‚Ä≤¬Ø‚å¢superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤x^{\prime}{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y^{\prime}.

Proposition 4

If the graph ùí¢‚Äã(ùí´,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí´‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}({\cal P},\mathcal{E}) is nùëõn-coloriable, then ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} has a labelling with 3‚Äãn3ùëõ3n colors.

Proof

For each equivalence class [x]delimited-[]ùë•[x] choose a labelling Œª[x]subscriptùúÜdelimited-[]ùë•\lambda_{[x]} of [x]delimited-[]ùë•[x] with an alphabet with 333 letters. Let Œª0subscriptùúÜ0\lambda_{0} a coloring of the graph ùí¢‚Äã(ùí´,‚Ñ∞)ùí¢ùí´‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}({\cal P},\mathcal{E}) and define Œª‚Äã(x)=(Œª[x]‚Äã(x),Œª0‚Äã([x]))ùúÜùë•subscriptùúÜdelimited-[]ùë•ùë•subscriptùúÜ0delimited-[]ùë•\lambda(x)=(\lambda_{[x]}(x),\lambda_{0}([x])). Then ŒªùúÜ\lambda is a labelling of ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E}: if x‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãyùë•¬Ø‚å¢ùë¶x{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y and [x]=[y]delimited-[]ùë•delimited-[]ùë¶[x]=[y], then Œª[x]‚Äã(x)=Œª[y]‚Äã(x)‚â†Œª[y]‚Äã(y)subscriptùúÜdelimited-[]ùë•ùë•subscriptùúÜdelimited-[]ùë¶ùë•subscriptùúÜdelimited-[]ùë¶ùë¶\lambda_{[x]}(x)=\lambda_{[y]}(x)\neq\lambda_{[y]}(y) and otherwise, if [x]‚â†[y]delimited-[]ùë•delimited-[]ùë¶[x]\neq[y], then [x]‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äã[y]delimited-[]ùë•¬Ø‚å¢delimited-[]ùë¶[x]{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}[y] so that Œª0‚Äã([x])‚â†Œª0‚Äã([y])subscriptùúÜ0delimited-[]ùë•subscriptùúÜ0delimited-[]ùë¶\lambda_{0}([x])\neq\lambda_{0}([y]). ‚àé

The reader should remark that Proposition 4 generalizes Proposition 2. The Proposition also suggests that a finite upper bound for the labelling number of event structures of degree 333 might indeed exist.

¬†¬† We conclude the paper by exemplifying how to use the Labelling Theorem on trees and the previous Lemma to construct a finite upper bound for the labelling number of event structures that we call simple due to their additional simplifying properties. Consider the event structure on the right and name it ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S}. In this picture we have used dotted lines for the edges of the Hasse

diagram of ‚ü®E,‚â§‚ü©ùê∏\langle E,\leq\rangle, simple lines for maximal concurrent pairs, and double lines for minimal conflicts. Concurrent pairs x‚å¢y‚å¢ùë•ùë¶x\raisebox{2.0pt}{$\frown$}y that are not maximal, i.e. for which there exists x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤superscriptùë•‚Ä≤superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤x^{\prime},y^{\prime} such that x‚Ä≤‚Äã‚å¢¬Ø‚Äãy‚Ä≤superscriptùë•‚Ä≤¬Ø‚å¢superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤x^{\prime}{\,\raisebox{-1.0pt}{$\overline{\frown}$}\,}y^{\prime} and either x<x‚Ä≤ùë•superscriptùë•‚Ä≤x<x^{\prime} or y<y‚Ä≤ùë¶superscriptùë¶‚Ä≤y<y^{\prime}, are not drawn. We leave the reader to verify that a nice labelling of ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} needs at least 444 letters. On the other hand, it shouldn‚Äôt be difficult to see that a nice labelling with 444 letters exists. To obtain it, take apart events with at most 111 lower cover from the others, as suggested in the picture. Use then the results of the previous section to label with three letters the elements with at most one lower cover, and label the only element with two lower covers with a forth letter.

A formalization of this intuitive method leads to the following Definition and Proposition.

Definition 9

We say that an event structure is simple if

  1. 1.

    it is graded, i.e. 0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(x)=0‚Äãp‚Äãt‚Äã(y)‚àí10ùëùùë°ùë•0ùëùùë°ùë¶10pt(x)=0pt(y)-1 whenever x‚â∫yprecedesùë•ùë¶x\prec y,

  2. 2.

    every size 333 clique of ùí¢‚Äã(‚Ñ∞)ùí¢‚Ñ∞\mathcal{G}(\mathcal{E}) contains a minimal conflict.

The event structure ùíÆùíÆ{\cal S} is simple and proves that even simple event structures cannot be labeled with just 333 letters.

Proposition 5

Every simple event structure of degree 333 has a nice labelling with 121212 letters.

Proof
